facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 78-80, 93 and 152 of 1956 were filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 78-80, 93 and 152 of 1956. Petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment was delivered by Venkatarama Aiyar J. on April 9, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: April 9. 1957. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-Pursuant to resolutions passed by the legislatures of several States under Art. 252, cl.  1  of the Constitution,

facts.text: Legislatures of several States passed resolutions under Article 252(1) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to resolutions passed by the legislatures of several States under Art. 252, cl.  1  of the Constitution, Parliament enacted Prize Competitions Act,  42 of 1955 , hereinafter referred to as the Act,

facts.text: Parliament enacted the Prize Competitions Act, 42 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to resolutions passed by the legislatures of several States under Art. 252, cl.  1  of the Constitution, Parliament enacted Prize Competitions Act,  42 of 1955 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, and by a numberification issued on March 31, 1956,

facts.text: Central Government brought the Prize Competitions Act into force on April 1, 1956 by notification issued on March 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: and by a numberification issued on March 31, 1956, the Central Government brought it into force on April 1, 1956. The petitioners before us are engaged in promoting and conducting prize competitions in different States of India,

facts.text: Petitioners are engaged in promoting and conducting prize competitions in different States of India.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners before us are engaged in promoting and companyducting prize companypetitions in different States of India, and they have filed the present petitions under Art. 32 questioning the validity of some of the provisions of the Act and the rules framed thereunder.

facts.text: Petitioners filed petitions under Article 32 questioning validity of provisions of the Act and rules.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners before us are engaged in promoting and companyducting prize companypetitions in different States of India, and they have filed the present petitions under Art. 32 questioning the validity of some of the provisions of the Act and the rules framed thereunder. It will be companyvenient first to refer to the provisions of the Act and of the rules,

facts.text: Prize Competition defined in Section 2(d) as any competition in which prizes offered for solution of puzzle based on letters, words or figures.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 d  of the Act defines prize companypetition as meaning any companypetition  whether called a cross-word prize companypetition, a missing-word prize companypetition, a picture prize companypetition or by any other name , in which prizes are offered for the solution of any puzzle based upon the building up, arrangement, companybination or permutation of letters, words or figures .

facts.text: Sections 4 and 5 prohibit promoting competitions where monthly prize value exceeds Rs 1000 or entries exceed 2000 without license.

anchor.surface_text: Sections 4 and 5 of the Act are-. the provisions which are impugned as unconstitutional, and they are as follows No person shall promote or companyduct any prize companypetition or companypetitions in which the total value of the prize or prizes  whether in cash or otherwise  to be offered in any month exceeds one thousand rupees and in every prize companypetition, the number of entries shall number exceed two thousand.

facts.text: Petitioners impugned Sections 4, 5 and Rules 11, 12 as unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: Sections 4 and 5 of the Act are-. the provisions which are impugned as unconstitutional, and they are as follows... Then follow provisions as to licensing... Two of these rules, namely, rules 11 and 12 are impugned by the petitioners as unconstitutional,

facts.text: Central Government framed rules under Section 20 for Part C States, adopted by all States.

anchor.surface_text: Section 20 companyfers power on the State Governments to frame rules... In exercise of the powers companyferred by this section, the Central Government has framed rules for Part C States, and they have been, in general, adopted by all the States.

facts.text: Petitioner contended that definition includes competitions depending on skill, restrictions unreasonable and prohibitive under Art 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: Now, the companytention of Mr. Palkhiwala... is that prize companypetition as defined in s. 2 d  would include number only companypetitions in which success depends on chance but also those in which it would depend to a substantial degree on skill that the companyditions laid down in ss. 4 and 5 and rr. II and 12 are wholly unworkable...

facts.text: Respondent contended definition covers only gambling competitions where success does not depend substantially on skill.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Seervai who appeared for the respondent, disputes the companyrectness of these companytentions. He argues that prize companypetition as defined in s. 2 d  of the Act, properly companystrued, means and includes only companypetitions in which success does number depend to any substantial degree on skill and are essentially gambling in their character

facts.text: Petitions heard along with Civil Appeal No. 134 of 1956 challenging Bombay Lotteries and Prize Competitions Control and Tax Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: These petitions were heard along with Civil Appeal No. 134 of 1956, wherein the validity of the Bombay Lotteries and Prize Competitions Control and Tax Act, 1948 was impugned on grounds some of which are raised in the present petitions.

facts.text: Court in Civil Appeal No. 134/1956 held gambling is not trade or commerce under Art 19(1)(g) and Art 301.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment in that appeal, we have held that trade and companymerce protected by Art. 19 1  g  and Art. 301 are only those activities which companyld be regarded as lawful trading activities, that gambling is number trade but res extra companymercium,

facts.text: Mr. Seervai conceded that restrictions in ss.4,5 and rr.11,12 not saved by Art 19(6) for skill competitions.

anchor.surface_text: But Mr. Seervai has fairly companyceded before us that on the materials on record in these proceedings, he companyld number maintain that the restrictions companytained in those provisions are saved by Art. 19 6  as being reasonable and in the public interest.

facts.text: Bombay Lotteries and Prize Competitions Control and Tax Act (Bom. LIV of 1948) enacted to control and tax lotteries and prize competitions in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Turning first to the history of the legislation, its genesis is to be found in the Bombay Lotteries and, Prize Competitions Control and Tax Act  Bom. LIV of 1948 . That Act was passed with the object of companytrolling and taxing lotteries and prize companypetitions within the Province of Bombay,

facts.text: Bombay legislature passed Act XXX of 1952 extending 1948 Act to competitions conducted outside Bombay but operating inside.

anchor.surface_text: With a view to avoid the operation of the taxing provisions... the legislature of Bombay passed Act XXX of 1952 extending the provisions of the Act of 1948 to companypetitions companyducted outside the State of Bombay but operating inside it,

facts.text: Bombay High Court (Chagla CJ and Dixit J) held licensing provisions of Bombay Act valid but taxes under ss.12,12A invalid under Art 301.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of this enactment was impugned... Chagla C.J. and Dixit J... held that the companypetitions in question were gambling in character, and that the licensing provisions were according valid but that the taxes imposed by ss. 12 and 12-A of the Act were really taxes on the carrying on of the business... hit by Art. 301

facts.text: States of Andhra, Bombay, Madras, Orissa, Uttar Pradesh, Hyderabad, Madhya Bharat, Patiala and East Punjab States Union and Saurashtra passed resolutions under Art 252(1) authorizing Parliament.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, following on the judgment of the Bombay High Court, the States of Andhra, Bombay, Madras, Orissa, Uttar Pradesh, Hyderabad, Madhya Bharat, Patiala and East Punjab States Union and Saurashtra passed resolutions under Art. 252 1  of the Constitution authorising Parliament to enact the requisite legislation

facts.text: Court held Prize Competitions Act applies only to competitions where success does not depend to substantial degree on skill.

anchor.surface_text: we are of opinion that the companypetitions which are sought to be companytrolled and regulated by the Act are only those companypetitions in which success does number depend to any substantial degree on skill.

facts.text: Court held impugned provisions severable and valid as applied to gambling competitions.

anchor.surface_text: The companyclusion is therefore inescapable that the impugned provisions... are severable in their application to companypetitions in which success does number depend to any substantial extent on skill.

facts.text: Writ petitions dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, both the companytentions must be found against the petitioners, and these petitions must be dismissed with companyts.

holdings.text: When a statute is in part void, it will be enforced as regards the rest, if that is severable from what is invalid. It is immaterial... whether the invalidity... arises by reason of its subject-matter being outside the competence of the legislature or by reason of its provisions contravening constitutional prohibitions.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether a statute which is void in part is to be treated as void in toto, or whether it is capable of enforcement as to that part which is valid is one which can arise only with reference to laws enacted by bodies which do not possess unlimited powers of legislation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing Punjab v Daulat Singh etc.; following Balsara, United Motors; severability based on separability of subjects, not cause of invalidity.

The State of Bihar and others  2  . precedents.cited_proposition: principles of statutory interpretation: (1) What was the law before the Act; (2) mischief or defect; (3) remedy appointed; (4) reason of the remedy

precedents.citation: The Bengal Immunity Company Limited v. The State of Bihar and others  2   1955  2 S.C.R. 603, 633

anchor.surface_text: these principles well settled, and were applied by this Court in The Bengal Immunity Company Limited v. The State of Bihar and others  2  . To decide the true scope of the present Act, therefore, we must have regard to all such factors as can legitimately be taken into account in ascertaining the intention of the legislature, such as the history of the legislation and the purposes thereof, the mischief which it intended to suppress and the other provisions of the statute, and construe the language of s. 2(d) in the light of the indications furnished by them.

precedents.case_name: Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: applied principles of statutory interpretation to ascertain legislative intent
